data.title: Champion sires
data.meta_description: https://twitter.com/AnaglogsDaughtr/status/1050141102232268802 Frankel regained the title he lost to Dubawi in 2022 to be champion in Britain/Ireland for a second time in 2023. His Group 1 winners included classic winners Chaldean (2000 Guineas) and Soul Sister (Oaks) along with Mostahdaf who won the Prince of Wales's Stakes and Juddmonte International Stakes.  Frankel was denied a second…
data.text:
Frankel regained the title he lost to Dubawi in 2022 to be champion in Britain/Ireland for a second time in 2023. His Group 1 winners included classic winners Chaldean (2000 Guineas) and Soul Sister (Oaks) along with Mostahdaf who won the Prince of Wales’s Stakes and Juddmonte International Stakes.

Frankel was denied a second successive champion sire title in France by his own son Cracksman who owed his position largely to the exploits of his unbeaten first-crop colt Ace Impact, winner of the Prix de l’Arc de Triomphe and Prix du Jockey Club.

Sea The Moon was champion sire for the first time in Germany, with his runners headed by Fantastic Moon who followed in his sire’s footsteps by winning the Deutsches Derby.

Into Mischief was champion in North America for the fifth year running where his leading earner was three-year-old filly Pretty Mischievous whose wins included the Kentucky Oaks, Acorn Stakes and Test Stakes.

Deep Impact‘s eleven-year reign as Japan’s champion was ended with Duramente taking the title posthumously. His notable representatives were fillies’ triple crown winner and Japan Cup runner-up Liberty Island, Stars On Earth who was placed four times at Group 1 level, including in the Japan Cup and Arima Kinen, and Kikuka Sho winner Durezza. Duramente died in the spring of 2021.

Il Campione was Argentina’s leading sire for the second year running, with a couple of G1-winning three-year-old colts among his best runners, Edict and El Encinal, the latter winner of the Gran Premio Carlos Pellegrini.

I Am Invincible was Australia’s champion sire for the third year running in 2023/24 while Savabeel reclaimed the New Zealand title to win it for a ninth time.

The list below includes champion sires in Argentina, France, Germany, Great Britain & Ireland and North America from 1900, in Australia and New Zealand from the 1900/01 season, and in Japan from 1942.

Each stallion’s year of birth, along with sire and dam is given (sire in bold indicates he also appears in the list) with country and year(s)/season(s) in which he was champion. Any stallion sons who were themselves champion sires are shown. An asterisk before a stallion’s name indicates he was also a champion sire prior to 1900. Clicking on highlighted stallions will link to their page at Thoroughbred Heritage which gives a lot more details. See also notes that follow.

Notes:

The following broodmares are dams of more than one champion sire in the above list: Cinna (Balloch, Beau Pere), Fairy Bridge (Fairy King, Sadler’s Wells), Hamoaze (Buchan, St Germans), Plucky Liege (Admiral Drake, Bull Dog, Sir Gallahad), Scapa Flow (Fairway, Pharos) and Selene (Hyperion, Sickle).

The following stallions were champions in more than one country: Beau Pere (Australia, New Zealand), Blandford (France, GB/Ireland), Court Harwell (GB/Ireland, Argentina), Cyllene (GB/Ireland, Argentina), Danehill (Australia, France, GB/Ireland), Dubawi (France, GB/Ireland), Frankel (France, GB/Ireland), Galileo (France, GB/Ireland), Limond (Australia, New Zealand), Lyphard (France, North America), Nasrullah (GB/Ireland, North America), Pharos (France, GB/Ireland), Sadler’s Wells (France, GB/Ireland) and Sir Tristram (Australia, New Zealand).

Although never champion sire himself, Precipitation (foaled in 1933, by Hurry On), sired Agricola, Chamossaire, Count Rendered, Sheshoon and Summertime.
